response.answer_text: No. Please understand that under modern law, copyright is automatic. The moment you record your music in a “fixed form”, it is copyrighted. (And understand as well that “copyright” is not “copy protection”; copyright is a set of laws, and the rights you gain under those laws, not some software that prevents copying.) So, DistroKid can’t copyright your music. It’s already copyrighted. Now, while copyright is automatic, registration of copyright is not. To register your copyright, you have to file forms with a copyright registry and, with most registries, pay a fee. Some countries’ governments have a registry — the US does, for example. In other countries, copyright registries are private entities operating under government regulation, and some countries don’t have registries as all. DistroKid operates in the US, so if they were going to register your copyright on your behalf, they’d have to do so with the US government (and they’d need your permission, which would likely be in their terms of service). I’ll note, though, that registering copyright on a song costs $35, or $55 to register up to ten unpublished works together as a group. Given that DistroKid’s annual fee is less than that, it seems extremely unlikely that they register copyright on your behalf. If they registered any number of songs for you as part of the service they’re providing for $20 a year, they’d rapidly go bankrupt.
